messages: 467f6d43402c6573237052cefcc252db (10:55): Hixie, I basically haven't found time to work on CSSOM for the past year or so
467f6d43402c6573237052cefcc252db (10:56): Hixie, though resize and scroll could I suppose be part of the subset that is CSSOM Vie

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:01): What happens if I have some HTML like <body bgcolor="black"><article><font color="white">... and the <article> contents ends up in a feed? ill it be unreadable? Taking some but not all style information seems like it could be dangerous
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (11:03): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: Well, that's "wrong" to begin with
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:03): Under the assumption that anything that works in a UA is conforming
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (11:03): You should set text color on the body element as well
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (11:04): Always specify foreground and background together
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:04): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9: According to whom? Not according to the supposed no-author-requirements HTML spec
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (11:05): According to the best practices that are supposed to replace them
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (11:05): No requirements includes the freedom to shoot yourself in the foot
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:06): Yeah but I'm trying to work out why that's a good thing
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (11:06): Has anyone claimed that?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:07): That having no author requirements is a good thing? Sure
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (11:07): That's a choice between evils, not goods
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:07): Can you explain more?
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (11:07): Requirements come with ratholes, bikesheds, and aren't enforced
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (11:08): The argument (as I read it) goes that avoiding all those weighs up for the loss of the guideance authority that could be provided
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:08): Lack of requirments will come with a huge rathole, at the bottom of which will be the original ratholes but renamed "best practices"
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:09): So I don't see any possibility for gain here
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (11:09): That is the gain
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (11:09): That huge rathole will always be there, that's what good authoring is all about
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (11:09): But without requirements, we outsource the war over where the hole should be

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:10): As far as I can tell the main agenda here is that some people don't like the HTML5 draft because it doesn't endorse something that they hold dear to them. So they have decided that the only way out is to try to remove all restrictions and be told "do what you like"
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (11:10): Well, the basic complaint holds: What use are requirements that no one actually requires?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:11): Sometimes this is wrapped up in theoretical RFC 2119 arguments

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:12): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9: The point of authoring requirements in a language with error correcting clients is not to describe the only possible way of doing things
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:12): It is to reduce the authoring surface of the language so that it does not grow without bounds and so there are as  few sharp edges as possible
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (11:13): But nobody reads those requirements
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:13): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9: Demonstrably untrue
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (11:13): They read second- or third-hand references that also includes local author intent, best practices, misconceptions, urban legends, etc etc

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:14): There has been a huge movement toward following standards. Yes there is a lot of cargo cult nonsense. But there is enough essentially good stuff that we should no thro the whole thing away just to make the lives of spec authors better
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:14): We even have a design principle about that
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (11:14): Nobody's saying we should throw it away
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (11:15): They may think so
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (11:15): But those references people use will still exist
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (11:15): It's only mark's assholes that will be weakened

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:17): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9: I would expect one effect of removing conformance requirements to be that people will start to reject HTML5 for cargo-cult reasons
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (11:17): Oh, sure. But there wouldn't be anything for them to reject. It would be a user agent spec full and whole.
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:18): It still will define a language
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:18): It just won't tell you which bits are a really bad idea
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (11:18): Now we're back at html4 ground
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (11:18): The language in the spec does not matter for authors, authors and users only go via user agents
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:19): But we just discussed this. Authors learn from somewhere and that somewhere often has looked at the spec
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:19): And authors do use vaidators
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:20): and validators have read the spec for sure
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (11:20): But again the authors don't go directly to the spec
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (11:20): They see the validator's rules, which would include all kinds of best practices
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:21): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9: What kind of best practices are encoded by validator.w3.org or validator.nu, beyond what is in the spec?
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (11:21): All the author requirements
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:22): I mean today
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (11:22): Today there isn't much need, henri gets it put into the spec instead
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (11:22): In particular the downplayed errors, he seems to be the main driving force there
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:23): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9: The concept of downplayed errors is silly
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:23): That is a UI issue
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (11:23): If so, that strenghtens the point

a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (11:24): These are things he doesn't want the validator to mark as errors. Now he's working inside the spec, if the spec dropped author reqs he would just go ahead and do it directly
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (11:24): What if someone else writing a different validator has different ideas of what should be considered an error or a warning?

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:25): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9: So in the future what do you envison? validator.w3.org uses best practices document A. commercial.validator.org uses weaker best practices document B to iucrease marketshare. Validator validate.net is written by areholes and has a whole load of additional requirements. An author tries to validate her document. What does she conclude?
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (11:25): Then you get competition in who validates the best
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (11:25): Putting those requirements in the spec prevents the benefits of competition, because there will only be one official blessed notion of validity
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (11:25): which seems similar to the argument against putting machine-readable schemas in the spec
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:25): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9: Re: dowwnplayed errors, Henri can already choose to downplay any error he likes. It is a pure UI issue

a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (11:26): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: Again, sure. It's not material to my point. The point is that he puts effort into convincing Hixie to mark them as downplayed. That means he cares.

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:27): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: The problem with putting schemas in the spec is that it is not possible to express all conformance requirements in schema and there is the possibility of divergence between the actual requirements and the schema (due either to the limitations or to bugs)
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (11:28): This situation exists even now, of course
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (11:28): There are requirements outside the HTML5 spec

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:28): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9: And I still maintain it is silly to have the requirements in the spec. So I don't see that I'm taking an inconsistent position
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (11:28): This whole thing would just be moving one set of requirements into some other (possible more than one) location
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:29): s/requirements/downplayed errors/

a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (11:29): It's not your position. His effort suggests that even if the spec did not have author requirements, he personally cares enough about these issues that his validator would have best practices for them
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (11:30): So no, validators would not just be windows onto the UA spec
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:30): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9: I don't understand your argument at all
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:30): specifically the sentence "validators would not just be windows onto the UA  spec

a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (11:31): [10:17:05] &lt b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea> a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9: What kind of best practices are encoded by validator.w3.org or validator.nu, beyond what is in the spec?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:31): "The spec" in this case is not just a "UA spec" though
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (11:32): Now we're just repeating ourselves

a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (11:32): The validator doesn't have its own requirements because they're in the spec. If they're not in the spec, they would be in the validator instead (so the validator itself wouldn't change)

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:34): There is no disagreement about what the requirements are. There is only the issue of whether some errors should be displayed with greater weight. That, to me, is a UI issue and I think that it shouldn't be in the spec

a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (11:35): Leave that issue. It's just an example to show that henri personally cares about some of the requirements, to support the claim that the validator would still have requirements if they weren't in the spec
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:35): So I disagree with Henri here. But I don't feel bad about it too much because I disagree with Henri less than almost anyone else involved with HTML5 :)

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:36): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9: Your argument seems totally unjustified. Unless you can point to things that are not in the spec but Henri has included as requirements anyway I don't think that you can conclude that he would do such a thing
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:37): I also don't think it's very relevant to whether, overall, there is any benefit to be gained by removing all the author requirements from HTML5
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:37): Anyway, I guess I should do something more useful...
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (11:38): We were there earlier
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (11:39): It's related because it claims that validators wouldn't change much. And validators and non-primary sources are where authors go
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (11:39): => Things would not change for authors and users
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:40): I still disagree but there se go

a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (11:40): Sure, you might get small civil wars over what best practices are best, but that would be hidden to most people. And it already happens, just look at WCAG Samurai

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:43): Actually the accessibility space is a great example of wwhy this kind of thing can be a disaster. There are so many documents relating to WCAG that it is almost impossible to tell where you should look for any given thing. And so you ask an "expert" and get an answer. And ask another "expert" and get a different answer. And so on...

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (11:44): Does anyone take any notice of the WCAG Samurai's suggestions, or is it evidence that everyone just follows the most official sounding guidelines (from the W3C) and ignores everything else regardless of merits?
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (11:44): I think the evidence is that people ignore everything, period
